body:
Deron, thanks for the fix. Couple of comments:
the inmemory JAR file is 15 MB now, but it used to be 9 MB. 6MB more than 
it used to be. Same thing happened to standalone jar which is 31 MB which 
is 6 MB more than it used to be. Wondering what changed.
JMLCExample:   using readScript() to read the mtx data file looks a little 
odd ... Want to just create an in-memory toy array to have some example 
data, which would also simulate the in-memory hand-over of the application 
data to SystemML?
an exhanced example, or additonal example should show that you can invoke 
.executeScript() several times with different data, and without preparing 
the script again.
up to you whether you want to show the compile/run for the example to 
highlight the use of the inmemory jar file:
COMPILE: javac -cp systemml-0.10.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-inmemory.jar -d bin 
-s src src/JMLCExample.java
RUN: java -cp systemml-0.10.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-inmemory.jar:bin 
JMLCExample

Regards,
Berthold Reinwald
IBM Almaden Research Center
office: (408) 927 2208; T/L: 457 2208
e-mail: reinwald@us.ibm.com

From:   Deron Eriksson notifications@github.com

Cc:     Berthold Reinwald/Almaden/IBM@IBMUS
Date:   03/22/2016 10:29 AM
Subject:        Re: [incubator-systemml] [SYSTEMML-586] Fix in-memory 
distribution for JMLC (#94)

@bertholdreinwald I updated the inmemory.xml file to include several 
libraries that were required to run the JMLC example. Please let me know 
if this is how the in-memory jar should be packaged.
â€”
You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub

@bertholdreinwald 
I compared the new in-memory jar with an old version on my machine from last summer (system-ml-5.0-SNAPSHOT-inmemory.jar). The old version was 9M but is missing classes needed in order to run. For example, if I run the JMLCExample with the old jar (and update the import packages to the old packages), I get "java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/apache/hadoop/conf/Configuration". 

BTW, the size discrepancies were mainly from the following directories (unpacked):
org/apache/commons (3.2M new vs 0M old)
org/apache/hadoop (16.1M new vs 6.3M old)
org/apache/log4j (706K new vs 0 old)
org/apache/wink (160K new vs 0 old)
org/slf4j (73K new vs 0 old)
META-INF/maven (~190K new vs ~30K old)
SystemML files (8.08M new vs 7.37M old)
root directory files (110K new vs 0 old)

thanks, Deron!

Regards,
Berthold Reinwald
IBM Almaden Research Center
office: (408) 927 2208; T/L: 457 2208
e-mail: reinwald@us.ibm.com

LGTM - thanks @asurve Just out of curiosity: Where do you intend to use the UtilFunctions.compareTo? In order to support sparse cells we would need to extend this with appropriate null checks as well.

I am not so sure about the usefulness of this inmemory jar any longer. Originally (back in the days, still with our ant build) it was meant to package - in a very fine-grained manner - only files that are actually needed when running in a pure in-memory scoring setting (e.g., all hadoop file system implementations and a lot of SystemML internal stuff like MR or Spark instructions are just unnecessary there but people are concerned with the footprint of their UDF jars which package and call SystemML). Furthermore, the plan was to introduce a runtime mode which would prevent the instantiation of JobConf and alike to reduce the required classes to very few APIs. Let's keep this jar for now but once we create the separate build for SystemML's core block runtime we might want to reconsider alternatives.
Thanks, its used in test program FrameCopyTest.java, which was not checked in, but its now. Please look into it. thanks
Closed via c26a3b030ea5837f5d809a08fa8b4d13c90a4617.
cc @deroneriksson, @lresende

thanks @asurve; this is a good start - couple of comments though:

1) Binary Block Writer: The method writePartitionedBinaryBlockFrameToHDFS is not required and can be removed. Also please put a comment in there that this write uses fixed size blocks with block-encoded keys. In the future, we might change that, especially the keys (e.g., starting offset).
2) CSV File Merge: the methods  mergeCSVPartFiles and addHeaderToCSV work on bytes. Hence there is no need to replicate them here for frames.
3) Null Checks: Keep in mind that frames might contain sparse cells (w/ null objects). You need to handle this when trying to convert them to strings. Also, for textcell, sparse cells should not be materialized into the output (it's a sparse format).
4) String Conversions: The cast to string for CSV and textcell would crash for any schema other than ValueType.STRING. Please, use UtilFunctions.objectToString() here.

Thank you @dusenberrymw. This is really great!

Couple things:
1) On line 1050 of spark-mlcontext-programming-guide.md, should "prod_i" be "prod_j"? (max_prod_j = X_train.select(F.max("prod_i")).first()[0])
2) On line 1001, the download link is empty "...can be downloaded [here]()". Should we mention the path in the project to the file rather than having a download link, or should we include this example notebook file under docs/ so that it can be easily downloaded from the online documentation? I guess I would lean towards the second approach since that is most convenient for the end user, and this example is a special notebook example since it is included in the official documentation. What are your thoughts?

@deroneriksson Great catches.  I've fixed the first one, and for the second, I'd like to have the link point to the raw file in the GitHub repo.  So, in that case it will still download as easily, but we don't have to maintain two separate files.

Also, I added two links: one to the (future) location on GitHub, which will automatically render the notebook as if it was opened locally, and one link to the raw download.

Here's what the rendered notebook looks like in GitHub: https://github.com/dusenberrymw/incubator-systemml/blob/Add_Jupyter_Examples/samples/jupyter-notebooks/SystemML-PySpark-Recommendation-Demo.ipynb.

@dusenberrymw Great! Linking to the raw notebook file in the GitHub repo sounds good. At some point before our 1.0 release, we might want to revisit the issue since if it's packaged under docs/, we can have in-sync snapshots of the entire documentation site for each release version.

Great job. LGTM.
Yeah, definitely.  Thanks!

@mboehm7 Alternatives sound like a good idea.

@bertholdreinwald I updated the JMLC example. It can be previewed [here](http://deroneriksson.github.io/incubator-systemml/jmlc.html). Let me know if further updates are needed or if this is sufficient.
I'm sorry for the wrong direction, but instead of UtilFunctions.objectToString, we should just call toString for objects !=null. Thanks.
LGTM

thanks @asurve  It would be good to reuse the internal arrays as well - otherwise there would be no point of such a reset functionality. You can do that by simplify setting the size of each column to 0 (the implementation already differentiated between logical size and physical length in order to allow exponential resizing for log resizing steps).
LGTM - thanks @Wenpei
Please check latest changes.
Merged.  Thanks, @Wenpei!
@Wenpei Can you move this to `./scripts/staging`?  Then the next steps will be to merge this, and then build some large-scale tests to stress it.

LGTM

Regards,
Berthold Reinwald
IBM Almaden Research Center

@mboehm7 Is this the proper way to set this information?
Can an Admin verify this patch?
LGTM

Although it works, I would expect the setup of positions and filenames during initial parsing (e.g., DmlSyntacticValidator) for atomic expressions and the propagation for composite expressions either in the syntactic parser or during validate. Also please use the one-liner 'setAllPositions'. Thanks @deroneriksson

thanks @ethanyxu - the addition of "if-else if-else" is useful but the "[ ]" indicates that the else branch is optional. Maybe you can merge both into meta level (both else-if and else branches are optional but else-if can occur many times)

1) Please, remove any IOExceptions from the FrameBlock api as the block itself will never do IO and hence this is misleading.
2) The reset call needs to cleanup the schema and column names too
3) Also, please don't mix the code for reset/allocation with the copy of schema because it should be possible to call reset on an empty block as well.
4) Why are the copy parameters rlen, clen, and rlDest required - isn't this redundant to rl, ru, cl, cu, and src?
Ah I see thanks for the clarification. I included both 'else if' and 'else' both in the main syntax body with '[]'. Also reworded the description to reflect the change.

Addressed changes from point 1 (residue from other change), 2, and 3. Partially from 4.
Wrt comment 4, I keept rlen, and clen to be consistent with other copy functions, but removed now.
   I need rldest, as need to know which position data to be copied, information is not available in any other source other than this parameter.
LGTM - I'm still not 100% happy with the copy signature but I'll clean this up whenever I touch it the next time

@ethanyxu could you please do one more cleanup: remove the sentence starting "The statement(s) in any of three bodies must be surrounded by braces ..." as this is not required and maybe even add a hint that we actually support this.

thanks @asurve - could you please consolidate writeAndVerifyBinaryBlockData, writeAndVerifyTextCSVData, and writeAndVerifyTextCellData into a single method that simply goes through FrameWriterFactory?
thanks, addressed the change
it goes into the right direction but why can't we just use FrameReaderFactory and FrameWriterFactory to avoid handling input and output infos - that's exactly what they're meant for, right?
yes, I should have. I did the change. I have added another signature FrameReaderFactory.createFrameReader(iinfo, prop) to be consistent with FrameWriterFactory and to avoid burden on caller.

ok great - just two more things:
1) you don't need to specify both InputInfo and OutputInfo - you can always get the corresponding input/output with InputInfo.getMatchingOutputInfo or OutputInfo.getMatchingInputInfo
2) there is a redundant semicolon in FrameReadWriteTest, line 170
Sure. It's edited accordingly.
LGTM - @asurve could you please double check that the tests are still working after merging. Thanks.
LGTM - thanks @ethanyxu
@mboehm7 Moved to CommonSyntacticValidator. Let me know if this is satisfactory.
@shirisht @mboehm7 Are any other modifications required, or is this ready for merging? Thank you.

Example of error which would occur when running Functions1.dml prior to this patch:

org.apache.sysml.parser.LanguageException: ERROR: null -- line 0, column 0 -- function square is undefined in namespace .defaultNS
    at org.apache.sysml.parser.StatementBlock.isMergeableFunctionCallBlock(StatementBlock.java:201)
    at org.apache.sysml.parser.StatementBlock.mergeFunctionCalls(StatementBlock.java:328)
    at org.apache.sysml.parser.DMLTranslator.liveVariableAnalysis(DMLTranslator.java:165)
    at org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.execute(DMLScript.java:585)
    at org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.executeScript(DMLScript.java:332)
    at org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.main(DMLScript.java:191)
LGTM.
LGTM

Given the following DML:

```
boo();
x=blah();
print("1", "2");
write();
```

Currently the parse errors are logged to log4j. If the user does not have log4j configured, the user gets the following output:

```
Exception in thread "main" org.apache.sysml.api.DMLException: org.apache.sysml.parser.ParseException: One or more errors found during parsing (could not construct AST for file: example.dml). Cannot proceed ahead.
    at org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.executeScript(DMLScript.java:344)
    at org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.main(DMLScript.java:191)
Caused by: org.apache.sysml.parser.ParseException: One or more errors found during parsing (could not construct AST for file: example.dml). Cannot proceed ahead.
    at org.apache.sysml.parser.dml.DMLParserWrapper.parse(DMLParserWrapper.java:98)
    at org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.execute(DMLScript.java:581)
    at org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript.executeScript(DMLScript.java:332)
    ... 1 more
```

A stacktrace is mostly useless for a user who is writing DML and has parse issues in the DML. In addition, the above message does not tell the user anything about the parse issues that actually occurred.

If the above DML is executed with the code in this PR, the user sees the following to standard error:

```
--------------------------------------------------------------
The following 3 parse issues were encountered:
#1 example.dml [line 1:0] [Validation error] -> boo();
   function call needs to have lvalue (Quickfix: change it to 'tmpVar = boo(...)')
#2 example.dml [line 3:0] [Validation error] -> print("1", "2");
   print() has only one parameter
#3 example.dml [line 4:0] [Validation error] -> write();
   incorrect usage of write function (at least 2 arguments required)
--------------------------------------------------------------
```

This output contains the information that the user actually needs to fix the user's DML. Additionally, the stacktrace information isn't included since this information is distracting and not useful for a user trying to fix parse errors in the DML.

This PR also makes this information avaible via ParseException so that it is available at higher levels of the call stack, which can help when handling parse situations in a notebook, for example.

This PR also contains other fixes and updates.
All tests passed in [PR build 240](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/240/).

All tests also passed in [OnDemand build 134](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/134/) which was rerun since previous [OnDemand build 133](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/133/) showed 1 failure in  org.apache.sysml.test.integration.applications.pydml.L2SVMPyDMLTest.

Note pre-existing behavior sets namespace to '.defaultNS' in CommonSyntacticValidator.getQualifiedNames for any function call that does not specify namespace.  The approach in this PR was to override that setting for an imported custom (i.e., non-built-in) non-qualified function call using the namespace specified in source statement which gets passed to the SyntacticValidator for validating the imported file.
LGTM.
LGTM, but it would be great to double check if this fix also applies to external functions or if additional extensions are required.

Not sure if I entirely understand WRT external functions, but if I try to cause an issue with a function defined with externalFunction (use wrong number of args, have the java function throw an exception, etc), typically an error such as "Runtime error in program block generated from statement block between lines 7 and 7" is generated.  Let me know if you'd like me to handle a specific external function situation. I will go ahead and merge this PR.
Added commits to cover custom functions with multiple return values.  PR 242 in progress.  Thank you @dusenberrymw for finding this case in grad_check.dml of deep learning library.
that's fine, please go ahead and merge the PR.

@gweidner Excellent!  I can confirm that the latest version works as intended.  I think this approach is simple, and introduces a good suite of tests to support the next stages of the UDF improvements.  Thanks!

LGTM.
@gweidner Looks like there are some merge conflicts now, can you fix them and then I can merge?

I've resolved the merge conflicts in DMLParserWrapper,java, PyDMLParserWrapper.java and force pushed the rebased commits.  The new tests added with this PR passed locally.  Full tests in progress at [PR build 243](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/243/).
Thanks again for reviewing and merging!
LGTM
Merged. Thanks @gweidner!

@dusenberrymw I move this script to staging. It's ready to merge now.

We will submit another PR for unit test, document.
LGTM
Can an Admin verify this patch?

thanks @ethanyxu that's a good catch - the example of 5 partitions is indeed wrong. 

Could you please slightly change the description: (1) it would be good to relax statements like "equal sized disjoint subsets" as the the outputs are not necessarily equal sized (they are _in expectation_ equal sized), (2) also, "randomly split" might create the wrong impression that sum(sv)=1 although you might very well have sum(sv)<1 and use it for sampling, (3) could you please break very long lines (e.g., line 23) and fix the indentation of lines 28-30? Thanks.
Can an Admin verify this patch?

thanks @nishi-t for bringing up this topic. In general, I think it would be useful to consistently change the number of max iterations to something like 10. However, the currently patch modified the wrong argument (intercept which has algorithm-specific meaning and only takes the values 0/1 or 0/1/2). For the maximum number of iterations please have a look at the arguments 'maxiter' and 'moi'/'mii'. That reminds me, it would be also useful to create consistency between the names of these arguments across all dml scripts. Furthermore, for small data, we might also want to introduce a number of runs (what you most likely were interested in modifying here, right).

thanks @deron that looks really good. Just two comments: 
(1) Could you please delete package-info.java (potentially move the java doc to connection) as most people only read class/method documentation. I've seen it in other projects too but our convention in SystemML is not to have these unnecessary files. You might want to bring up a discussion but let's separate this out.
(2) Non-zero arguments: Please, add to the nnz parameter description something like "-1 to indicate unknowns".

thanks @asurve  but this requires some work - please keep the intended distributed frame representation (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-560) in mind.

1) binaryBlock2CSV slice: The slicing of binary blocks to rows is not required for frames as each frame block covers all columns.
2) csv2BinaryBlock nnz: Without the CSVAnalysisFunction, the accumulator from which you try to obtain the nnz will always return 0. Furthermore, for frames we don't even maintain the nnz, so please remove the related code.
3) csv2BinaryBlock shuffle: The whole point of the variable length frameblocks is to prevent shuffle. Currently, the mergeBykey causes unnecessary shuffle and should be removed. Please, also delete the related MergeBlocksFunction and mergeByKey primitives.
4) Blocksize: Again, we want to create variable size blocks at the end of partitions, so we cannot use UtilFunctions.computeBlockSize which would always give you 1k, even at the end of partitions.
5) Tests: Please factor out your new testcases into a separate converter test class as it has nothing to do with frame read/write. Given this refactoring you could also drop the execution type as it is misleading because these are component tests not integration tests on dml script level.
I have addressed the changes.
Can an Admin verify this patch?

Most changes are cleanups and cosmetic. They look good.
LGTM
add to whitelist.
add to whitelist.

6) Binary block keys: on csv to binary block, it seems that we output the wrong keys (block indexes instead of block row offset) which is wrong with variable-sized blocks.
7) Formatting: Finally, there are also some formatting issues, e.g.,  FrameRDDConverterUtils, line 295.

Thanks, @Wenpei!

@niketanpansare Do you have any additional thoughts on this?  Moving to Scala for the MLPipeline-style wrappers should help us promote the plans for PR #108.

Note: I'm going to close this for now, but we should consider revisiting these ideas in the future with regards to quick fixes for print statements and string appends, as well as broader design decisions for native scalar outputs for full right-indexing (i.e. `X[1,3]`).
For user consumability, this would be a great addition.

@Wenpei @dusenberrymw +1 for keeping scala as default version and removing java mlpipeline wrappers. 

@Wenpei Please make sure that code works through spark-shell:
import org.apache.spark.ml.Pipeline
import org.apache.sysml.api.ml.LogisticRegression
import org.apache.spark.ml.evaluation.BinaryClassificationEvaluator
import org.apache.spark.ml.feature.{HashingTF, Tokenizer}
import org.apache.spark.ml.tuning.{ParamGridBuilder, CrossValidator}
import org.apache.spark.mllib.linalg.Vector
case class LabeledDocument(id: Long, text: String, label: Double)
case class Document(id: Long, text: String)
val training = sc.parallelize(Seq(
     LabeledDocument(0L, "a b c d e spark", 1.0),
     LabeledDocument(1L, "b d", 2.0),
     LabeledDocument(2L, "spark f g h", 1.0),
     LabeledDocument(3L, "hadoop mapreduce", 2.0),
     LabeledDocument(4L, "b spark who", 1.0),
     LabeledDocument(5L, "g d a y", 2.0),
     LabeledDocument(6L, "spark fly", 1.0),
     LabeledDocument(7L, "was mapreduce", 2.0),
     LabeledDocument(8L, "e spark program", 1.0),
     LabeledDocument(9L, "a e c l", 2.0),
     LabeledDocument(10L, "spark compile", 1.0),
     LabeledDocument(11L, "hadoop software", 2.0)))
val tokenizer = new Tokenizer().setInputCol("text").setOutputCol("words")
val hashingTF = new HashingTF().setNumFeatures(1000).setInputCol(tokenizer.getOutputCol).setOutputCol("features")
val lr = new LogisticRegression(sc, sqlContext)
val pipeline = new Pipeline().setStages(Array(tokenizer, hashingTF, lr))
val crossval = new CrossValidator().setEstimator(pipeline).setEvaluator(new BinaryClassificationEvaluator)
val paramGrid = new ParamGridBuilder().addGrid(hashingTF.numFeatures, Array(10, 100, 1000)).addGrid(lr.regParam, Array(0.1, 0.01)).build()
crossval.setEstimatorParamMaps(paramGrid)
crossval.setNumFolds(2)
val cvModel = crossval.fit(training.toDF)
val test = sc.parallelize(Seq(
      Document(12L, "spark i j k"),
      Document(13L, "l m n"),
      Document(14L, "mapreduce spark"),
      Document(15L, "apache hadoop")))
cvModel.transform(test.toDF).show

You may be missing the logic for getting the rawPrediction (which is required for CrossValidator): https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/ml/LogisticRegressionModel.java#L154
@deroneriksson Done.

All tests passed in [OnDemand build 143](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/143/).

As an additional manual test outside the unit tests, reused the deep learning scripts from SYSTEMML-618 and moved the workaround source statements to files that directly use the imported functions.  For example, modified tests.dml imported grad_check.dml and test.dml only.  Similarly, grad_check.dml and test.dml imported the files each one directly used.
Verified the revised tests.dml ran successfully.

Note [SYSTEMML-631](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-631) opened to address handling of potential namespace conflicts.
LGTM - thanks @asurve

thanks @gweidner - I would recommend to also add some tests with functions that are not inlined in order to test the runtime part as well. Right now we inline any "single-statement-block function" (recursively).  So for example a function with control flow like loops or branches would do the trick.
